text:
Back in 2016 Apple famously removed the headphone
jack from the iPhone 7, and while customers

and companies alike mocked Apple for releasing
a flagship smartphone without a headphone

jack, it eventually became clear within the
next couple years that the iPhone 7 had set

a trend that virtually every other smartphone
manufacturer would follow. This is Greg with

Apple Explained and I want to thank Hover
for sponsoring this video. If you want to

help decide which video topics I cover, make
sure you’re subscribed and these voting

polls will show up in your mobile activity
feed.

Now I want to start off by sharing some background
knowledge of the 3.5mm headphone jack. Which

is one of the most unique I/O ports to ever
exist, and there are a few reasons for this.

First, it was invented over fifty years ago
in the 1960’s, which means it came out before

the VCR player, a product many of you may
not even recognize since it’s been obsolete

for so long. But the headphone jack was able
to stand the test of time and remain relevant

even to this day. Which brings me to the second
thing that makes the port so special, it can

actually be upgraded with modern features
by simply adding another ring to its sleeve.

That’s why older headphone jacks only have
one or two rings, while today we’re used

to seeing three. And those extra rings added
capabilities like stereo audio and audio input,

without the need to redesign an entirely new
connector, not to mention modern headphones

are backward compatible with older products.
But there’s one more important quality of

the headphone jack, it served as a ubiquitous
industry standard for audio in and out.

Now what do I mean by that? Well, when a company
makes a product, they have to decide what

ports would be best to include. And different
companies made different decisions. I mean,

just look at all the different USB ports that
exist on the market today, companies have

to decide which one is best suited for their
product. That’s why you tend to have different

chargers for different devices. I can’t
charge my Nintendo Switch with my iPhone power

cable, and I can’t charge my MacBook Pro
with my external monitor’s power cable.

Different products tend to require different
ports. But the 3.5mm headphone jack is a rare

exception. Because it was basically adopted
by the entire tech industry, despite there

being many other options for audio as you
can see here. The fact that you could buy

an iPod and plug its headphones into literally
any other MP3 player on the market was an

incredible benefit that I think was often
overlooked. So it’s clear the headphone

jack is an exceptional piece of technology,
but in recent years, many tech companies have

decided not to include it in their products
anymore. And it all started with Apple.

In 2016, Apple held their annual press event
in the fall and fans from all over the world

were eager to see what the next generation
iPhone had in store, and hopes were very high.

Because after the incremental iPhone 6S release
the previous year, we knew the iPhone 7 was

due to receive a more dramatic update. Although
many were disappointed when the device was

revealed, mainly because its design was virtually
unchanged, but also because it was missing

a headphone jack. Which some users felt was
a must-have feature for a smartphone. It left

people wondering why Apple decided to remove
such an important port from their most popular

product. And what reason did Apple give? Well,
Phil Schiller gave three: [clip]

Now, I wish Phil Schiller would’ve left
out the statement about courage since it just

became an internet meme and overshadowed the
more legitimate reasons for removing the headphone

jack. Like the fact that it took up valuable
space inside the phone that could be used

for features like the Taptic Engine. Apple
was also able to include a 14% larger battery

which delivered an extra 1-2 hours of battery
life, and the iPhone 7 achieved an IP67 waterproofing

certification thanks to the absence of the
headphone jack. Not to mention the lightning

connector could serve as an audio port to
deliver even higher quality sound than before.

Lastly, the transition to wireless headphones
would happen faster if all smartphones ditched

the headphone jack. But there are two sides
to this story, so let me explain how some
users were feeling about Apple’s decision.

It seemed suspicious that the iPhone’s headphone
jack was removed at the same time the AirPods

were introduced. In fact, right after Phil
Schiller finished justifying ditching the

headphone jack, he announced their new wireless
headphones. Suggesting Apple was trying to

sell more AirPods by removing the iPhone’s
headphone jack and making it more inconvenient

to use traditional wired earbuds. Because
if you think about it, Apple could’ve waited

a year or two to remove the iPhone’s headphone
jack and allow more time for the industry

to transition to wireless, making things easier
for iPhone users, but they decided against

it. And when it comes to Apple’s argument
that the iPhone needed room for things like

its Taptic Engine, that may not be entirely
true. Because a YouTube channel called Strange

Parts was actually able to put a headphone
jack in an iPhone 7 himself without removing

any vital components. It’s actually an incredible
video that I highly recommend you watching,

you can find a link to it in the description.
There was also speculation that Apple was

trying to earn more money from royalties by
licensing their lightning connector to third

party headphone manufacturers, but I don’t
think that was as big a factor as some were
claiming.

Now as you can imagine there was a significant
amount of backlash from consumers and tech

bloggers over the removal of the headphone
jack from the iPhone 7. Some people even refused

to buy it for that reason alone. So how significantly
were iPhone sales effected? Well, sales of

the device didn’t appear to be effected
at all. Apple sold 38.9 million units in the

first quarter of 2017 which made the iPhone
7 and 7 Plus the best-selling smartphones

in the world. And most users didn’t seem
to miss the headphone jack, probably because

of the included adapter that allowed users
to connect their favorite wired headphones
anyway.

Now I should mention this wasn’t the first
time apple removed a popular component from

a product. They did it with the 1998 iMac
by removing the floppy drive, the 2008 MacBook

by removing the firewire port, the 2008 MacBook
Air by removing the CD drive, and the 2015

MacBook by removing the USB-A ports. And every
time this happened, Apple received criticism

from people in the tech community. But this
backlash was just the first phase of public

opinion, the second phase was when users began
adapting to the changes Apple made, and the

third phase happened once users admitted the
technology Apple left out was no longer necessary.

That’s why computers today don’t have
floppy drives and it’s very hard to find

notebooks that still include CD drives. And
the headphone jack is already following the

same trajectory. Because even though it was
only removed from the iPhone two and a half

years ago, other smartphone manufactures have
already begin to follow Apple’s lead. Samsung

removed the headphone jack from their Galaxy
A8s and Galaxy Fold, along with the Pixel

2, Moto Z3, OnePlus 6T, Xperia XZ2, HTC U12
Plus, Huawei Mate 20 Pro, and more. So clearly

there must be some benefit to removing the
headphone jack if virtually every major smartphone
manufacturer has already done it.

But I should mention that the headphone jack
isn’t only being removed from smartphones.

Apple also left it out of their new iPad Pros
in 2018, and some are wondering if they’ll

eventually remove it from their MacBook or
MacBook Air notebooks. So what does the demise

of the headphone jack actually mean for everyday
users? Well, it means you have two options:

carry around an adapter to use wired headphones
with your device, or buy wireless headphones

and never worry about plugging into a headphone
jack again. And if you’ve had any experience

with high quality wireless headphones, you
probably found it difficult to go back to

the wired equivalent. I remember when the
AirPods were first announced and people dismissed

them as overpriced and ugly. After all, you
could buy wired headphones with better sound

quality for the same price. But many people
underestimated the unbelievable level of convenience

AirPods provided. And that’s why they’ve
become such a huge success.

So I think most people would agree that the
future is wireless, but some may have a problem

with how we get there. As I mentioned before,
there is some truth to the fact that Apple

was very abrupt. Forcing users into an uncomfortable
position that could’ve been avoided if the

headphone jack had been included on iPhone
for at least another few years. Giving wireless

technology time to become more affordable
and widely adopted by users. But I think overall,

users weren’t bothered by Apple’s approach.
With some, like Jonathan Kim even calling

it a non-issue. And I actually think he made
a pretty good point when he said, “in 2018,

complaining about smartphones losing the 3.5mm
jack is actually advocating for more wires — which

get tangled, snagged, frayed, require you
to be attached to a device, and can lead to

devices getting damaged when they accidentally
get yanked to the floor or off your head.

And for audio, we simply don’t need wires
and the problems that go with them anymore.”
